Mars will next reach its bright opposition — when it swings close to Earth — on Feb. 19, 2027. — Jamie Carter If you watched last month's "planet parade", you'll have seen Mercury make a spectacular appearance alongside Venus and Jupiter. Its apparent journey to and from the sun's glare — from our point of view of Earth — is now on the wane, with an hour before sunrise today being the best time to be in position to see the "Swift Planet's" final appearance, close to bright star Regulus in the constellation Leo. Regulus will be just to the lower-right of Mercury. Be quick because both will fade long before sunrise. — Jamie Carter August is prime time to view the constellation Sagittarius, which lies across the busiest section of the Milky Way from the point of view of the solar system — the galactic center point. Dense starfields and nebulas abound in this part of the sky, but the easiest shape of stars to see resembles a teapot. Look to the southern horizon a few hours after sunset, and you'll see eight stars just to the left of the brightest part of the Milky Way, resembling a handle, teapot and spout. The teapot tips forward slightly, with the Milky Way acting as steam rising from its spout. — Jamie Carter Low on the southwest horizon, about 45 minutes after dark, you'll find a big, bright, waxing crescent moon just shy of its plump first quarter phase. It will be just to the lower-right of Antares, the brightest star in the summer constellation Scorpius, "The Scorpion." — Jamie Carter Rise at the latest an hour before sunrise and cast your eyes to the eastern horizon. You'll see a neat equilateral triangle with Jupiter at the top, the bright star Procyon at the bottom-right and super-bright Venus at the bottom-left. If the sky is dark enough and your eyesight is sharp, you'll notice a fuzzy patch on the left-hand side of Venus, close to the planet. That's the Beehive Cluster (M44), an open cluster of about 1,000 stars and one of the nearest to the solar system. Take along a pair of binoculars for the best view. — Jamie Carter Aug. 31 was the best time to catch Venus at its closest to the Beehive Cluster (M44) in the constellation Cancer, but about an hour and a half before sunrise on Sept. 1, the sight will still impress low on the east-northeast horizon. Shining at magnitude -3.9, Venus will be blazingly bright and easy to spot, though a pair of binoculars will make it easier to spot M44. From about an hour before sunrise, you may see Mercury rise into view at magnitude -2, with Venus equidistant between it and Jupiter at magnitude -1.4 above and to the east. — Jamie Carter If you have seen any "shooting stars" this season, there's a good chance that they will have been Perseids, which, as their name suggests, appeared to streak away from a point of origin located in the ancient constellation Perseus, "The Hero." Rising in the northeast is the W-shape of the constellation Cassiopeia as darkness falls. The most famous shape in Perseus is a curve of stars called the Segment of Perseus, with the bright star Miram in its center. Most of the stars in Perseus are in the Perseus Moving Group (also called the Alpha Persei Cluster), which is about 570 light-years from the solar system. — Jamie Carter Look to the southwest about 45 minutes after dark, and low on the horizon, you'll find a 21%-illuminated waxing crescent moon. To its right will be Spica, and beyond that, Mars. Look high above for the Big Dipper (The Plough), identifying the four stars that form its handle. Follow then in a curve to the next bright star — Arcturus in the constellation Boötes, which will be directly above Spica and Mars. You've just performed one of the most famous star-hops in stargazing — "Arc to Arcturus, spike to Spica." — Jamie Carter Look to the southwest to see the 14%-illuminated waxing crescent moon shine with Mars on its right and the bright star Spica on its left. Spica, the brightest star in the constellation Virgo, is 250 light-years from the solar system. — Jamie Carter Look due west about 30 minutes after the sun sets, and you may see one of the most delicate signs in all nature — a young moon. Just 8%-illuminated, a waxing crescent moon will shine just below and to the right of Mars. Although the red planet is still visible after sunset, it's now faint. — Jamie Carter It's August. The moon is down. That can mean only one thing. It's peak Milky Way season! Our home galaxy will look its very best tonight, with no moonlight in the sky. It's also at its most dramatic and convenient, visible, arcing from high in the southeast to the southern horizon, with the brightest part — the core, or galactic center point — low on the southern horizon. If you're struggling to see it, that's because you're looking at light-polluted skies. Get away from city lights — about 25 miles (40 km) south, where the southern horizon is dark — and you'll see it. Any newish smartphone boasting a "night mode" can take a decent image of the Milky Way, but do keep it still, either by using a tripod or simply resting it on something like a gatepost or table. — Jamie Carter Related: Black Moon darkens August skies — here's how to hunt sparking wonders in the Milky Way this weekend There's not much to see, but today, the moon reaches its new phase, slipping roughly between Earth and the sun to get lost in the glare of our star for a day or two. It will emerge as a crescent in the evenings to come. This month, the new moon has a special name — a "black moon." It's purely an astronomical term for the third new moon in a season with four new moons. Strictly speaking, it's a "seasonal black moon." Related: A rare Black Moon rises with the sun on Aug. 23: Here's what to expect Can you see a black moon? No — not this year — but it is possible during a solar eclipse when its silhouette is visible in eclipse glasses. That's exactly what happens one lunar year (12 orbits of the moon around the sun — 354 days) from today, when the next total solar eclipse on Earth is visible from Greenland, Iceland and Spain on Aug. 12, 2026. More importantly, with the "black moon" out of the sky altogether, it's a chance to take advantage of the increased hours of darkness to go stargazing. — Jamie Carter You'll never see Pluto with the naked eye. Or with a telescope, for that matter, unless it's incredibly powerful. However, it's useful to know where it is in the sky, and today is a good excuse, for 19 years ago — on Aug. 26, 2006 — the International Astronomical Union voted to approve a new definition of "planet" that excluded Pluto. Since then, it's been known as a dwarf planet. The discovery of a similarly sized body, Eris, prompted re-evaluation — and ultimately reclassification — of Pluto, hence the vote. Look high in the southeast just after dark for the Summer Triangle, that vast elongated asterism of three bright stars — Deneb and Vega at the top and Altair at the bottom. Come down to the horizon from Altair. About two-thirds of the way through that journey is the approximate position of Pluto. Since it takes 248 years to orbit the sun, its position doesn't change much from year to year. — Jamie Carter Head away from city lights and look high above the southern horizon a couple of hours after sunset on Aug. 21 to find the three stars of the famous 'Summer Triangle' asterism astride the Milky Way. Altair — the brightest star in the constellation Aquila — can be seen twinkling to the left of the Milky way, closest to the horizon, with bright Vega visible to its upper right on the other side of the galactic ribbon of stars, dust and gas. Deneb, the tail of the swan represented by the constellation Cygnus, will be visible embedded in the glowing band of the Milky Way to Vega's left, completing the cosmic triangle. It's going to be a challenging sight that requires a very clear eastern horizon and excellent timing, but how often do three exquisite celestial sights align in the night sky? If you can get some binoculars on Mercury as it rises (start looking about an hour before sunrise), look just above it for a sparkling clump of stars — the Beehive Cluster. Above and to the left of that will be an incredibly delicate, 4%-illuminated waning crescent moon. Thursday marks the eighth anniversary of the "Great American Eclipse," a total solar eclipse that crossed the U.S. on Aug. 21, 2017. That day, the NASA website's live broadcast got more than 50 million views and almost 31 million unique views on Facebook. The next one in the U.S. is on Aug. 23, 2044, in Montana and North Dakota. That's just 19 years from this Saturday! — Jamie Carter If you're going to rise early once this month, make it today because in the east, an hour before sunrise, the "planet parade" peaks. You can look for Mercury beneath and Jupiter above, but your eyes will be drawn to what's between the two — a spectacularly slender 9%-illuminated waning crescent moon next to bright Venus. Look just to the left of the moon and you'll see Pollux, one of the "twins" in the constellation Gemini. Just above it, you'll find its "brother," Castor. — Jamie Carter You may have glimpsed it already, but summer 2025's "planet parade" now begins its grandest phase. Be up and looking east an hour before sunrise and you'll see a now 16%-illuminated waning crescent moon form a slight curve with Jupiter and Venus. Today, Mercury reaches what astronomers call the "greatest elongation west," when the tiny "Swift Planet" reaches its farthest distance from the sun in the pre-dawn sky. — Jamie Carter The presence of a full moon this week has ruined the Perseid meteor shower's peak last Monday/Tuesday. Can we salvage anything? Perhaps. With the moon on the cusp of its last quarter phase, it won't rise until shortly before midnight. That gives sky-watchers a little time in dark skies to see what remains of the 100-or-so "shooting stars" that were buzzing around last Monday. You can look anywhere in the night sky, but know that the source constellation, Perseus, is rising in the northeast after sunset. Any "shooting stars" you do see are grains of dust left in the inner solar system by comet Swift-Tuttle. — Jamie Carter A last quarter moon is an important waymarker for stargazers, and this month, that goes double. It marks the point in the moon's orbit when it wanes to being half-lit, with it shrinking to an ever-slimmer crescent over the next week. As well as leaving the skies darker when it is present, a last quarter moon rises at midnight and about 50 minutes later each night thereafter, clearing the evening skies of any natural light pollution. As luck would have it, the half-lit moon will tonight rise just a few degrees above the sparkling open cluster of stars known as the Pleiades, or "Seven Sisters" — a favorite of many stargazers — in the constellation Taurus, "The Bull." — Jamie Carter Whisper it, but there's a must-see planetary conjunction building in the pre-dawn sky. Should you bother to get up for it? If you're only going to do so once, wait until Tuesday, Aug. 19, when the moon will be slimmer and Mercury will be highest — but if there's a clear sky forecast this morning, go for it. Your reward will be a 36%-illuminated waning crescent moon high above Jupiter, Venus and, closer to the eastern horizon, possibly Mercury. Be in place about an hour before sunrise. — Jamie Carter The "planet parade" gets even more impressive this morning before sunrise as a now 26%-illuminated waning crescent moon gets a little closer to Jupiter and Venus, with Mercury peeking above the eastern horizon as dawn approaches. Look for "Earthshine" on the crescent moon and, to the right of the planets, for the winter constellation of Orion "The Hunter" rising. Let the three stars in Orion's Belt point you towards the bright star Sirius on the east-northeast horizon. — Jamie Carter Some sights in the night sky are small but perfectly formed. Such an object is Brocchi's Cluster, also known as Collinder 399 and, more descriptively, as the Coathanger. Visible close to the Summer Triangle stars in the southeast after dark, Brocchi's Cluster does require dark skies, but it's more obvious than you might think. Almost exactly halfway between the bright stars Vega and Altair in the Summer Triangle, Brocchi's Cluster is about 10 easily visible stars in the shape of — you guessed it — a coat hanger, complete with hook. Just bear in mind that the coat hanger is upside down as viewed from the Northern Hemisphere. — Jamie Carter One of the smallest but oldest-named constellations, Sagitta, "The Arrow," is found between the bright stars Deneb and Altair (but much closer to the latter) in the Summer Triangle asterism high in the southeast after dark. It's only four stars, but they're arranged in a dramatic arrow shape that's unmistakable. It points towards the northern horizon. — Jamie Carter. It's a shame, but tonight's peak of the annual Perseid meteor shower isn't going to provide many "shooting stars." Although there can be as many as 100 per hour in the darkest hours of the peak night, a waning gibbous moon — about 91%-illuminated — will rise in the east just as it gets dark and will shine brightly for the rest of the night. That will bleach the sky and make the Perseids hard to see, but the brightest ones should still be visible. Be outside just before midnight and stand with your back to the bright moon for the best chance. — Jamie Carter In what has to be one of the celestial highlights of August, the two brightest planets in the solar system will come to within a degree of each other in the pre-dawn sky. Look to the east-northeast for the fabulous sight of the second and fifth planets from the sun appearing just a width of an outstretched finger apart. Be in place an hour before sunrise where you are to see the two brightest planets shine side by side — it's not something that happens too often. By the way, you'll hear lots of stories about six planets being "in alignment" this morning from people who have no idea what alignment means. Yes, Uranus is in the sky (high above Jupiter and Venus), and Neptune is close to Saturn beside the 89%-illuminated moon, but it's not an alignment — the planets all orbit on the same path through the sky, known as the ecliptic (the plane of the solar system). It's like saying cars align with each other on a road! — Jamie Carter If you've been watching the sky for some time, you'll have seen a full moon appear on the eastern horizon during dusk. It's an exquisite sight, but exactly which night to look can be tricky to tell in advance. The effect looks best when the full moon appears about 20 minutes after sunset, when the surrounding landscape is still slightly aglow from the recently set sun. That perfect time is tomorrow, but tonight, the almost full moon will rise almost simultaneously with the sunset. So get yourself a clear view of the eastern horizon and see summer's second full moon appear in a muted orange. Then come back tomorrow for a second helping — and a subtly different view. — Jamie Carter Read more: August full moon 2025 rises this weekend: Here's how to see the stunning 'Sturgeon Moon' At 3:56 a.m. EDT today, the moon will be 100%-illuminated by the sun and be at its full phase while in the constellation Capricornus, "The Goat." Although the conditions were good last night to watch an almost full moonrise, there's a second chance tonight. With the moon rising in the east about half an hour after sunset, the landscape should still be visible as a bright orange orb appears. Expect a dramatic sight. — Jamie Carter The Summer Triangle is an anchor of the seasonal night sky. Dominating the southeastern sky immediately after dark, its three bright stars — Deneb, Vega and Altair — can help stargazers navigate all summer long. Altair, in particular, can also act as a signpost to several night sky sights you could otherwise easily miss. One is a very tiny but beautiful constellation called Delphinus, "The Dolphin." Found just to the left of Altair soon after dark at this time of year, Delphinus is formed from five stars clustered close together, with the four making an unmistakable diamond shape. — Jamie Carter The heliacal rising of a star is the date when it first becomes visible in the east just before dawn, having previously been visible in the west just after sunset. For the brightest star in the night sky, Sirius, its heliacal rising holds an important place in human culture, and specifically in ancient Egypt, where it marked the beginning of a new year. The exact date you can see Sirius swap from the evening sky to the morning sky will depend on where you live. According to data from Sky & Telescope, subtract your latitude from 29 to get the date in August. For example, if you live at 50 degrees north, it's Aug. 21, while those at 40 degrees north will see Sirius before sunrise for the first time this year on Aug. 11. It will appear on the east-southeast horizon, with the three stars of a vertical Orion's Belt pointing straight down at it. — Jamie Carter The fourth brightest star in the nighttime sky, Arcturus, is the brightest in the constellation Boötes, "The Plowman." Its name means "Guardian of the Bear" in Greek because it's close to the Big Dipper/The Plough. This month, you can find it high above the western horizon. Relatively close to Earth at 37 light-years away, Arcturus sits at the bottom of a pattern of stars in the Boötes constellation that looks like a champagne flute. — Jamie Carter Having found Vega earlier this week, now look for Deneb, a bright star in the southeast that's the top-left corner of the Summer Triangle asterism. One of the most distant stars visible to the naked eye, Deneb, is approximately 1,500 light-years from the solar system. So why is it visible at all? A blue-white supergiant around 200 times larger than the sun, it's one of the most luminous stars in the Milky Way galaxy. — Jamie Carter Jupiter is currently shining in the pre-dawn sky just below Venus. Although it's a fine sight to the naked eye, put any pair of binoculars on the giant planet and its four large moons suddenly appear as points of light, just as they did to Galileo in 1610 when he put the first astronomical telescope up to his eye. Jupiter and its moons are currently being investigated by NASA's Juno probe, which was launched from Cape Canaveral Air Force Station, Florida, on Aug. 5, 2011 — exactly 14 years ago. Juno has been at Jupiter since 2016 and has made discoveries ranging from cyclones to Io's flowing magma. However, this is the last launch anniversary we can happily celebrate because Juno is scheduled to end its mission on September 15, 2025. Will it get an extended mission? In normal times, yes, but if Trump's 2026 budget call does slash NASA funding by 24%, Juno may end its mission prematurely. — Jamie Carter Stargazers often look for constellations and asterisms (shapes), but what about stars? If the constellations are just imaginary shapes in the night sky, the stars are real — the anchors and signposts — and not only do they look different, but many of them have names as old as human culture. Arguably, the most important star in the night sky is Vega, an anchor star of summer. A mere 25 light-years from the solar system, it's part of the Summer Triangle asterism in the southeast after dark. It's assigned zero magnitude because all other stars' brightness is measured relative to it. The second brightest in the Northern Hemisphere, Vega was the first to be photographed in 1850 and was imaged by the Hubble and James Webb Space Telescopes in 2024. — Jamie Carter Venus has dominated the post-sunset and, more recently, the pre-dawn night skies for all of 2025 so far. Its apparition as the bright "Morning Star" — as stargazers call it when it's visible before sunrise — peaks tonight as it reaches its highest altitude in the morning sky while in the hand of Orion, "The Hunter." Exactly how high it is will depend on where you are, but it's the easiest time to see Venus in the east before dawn this year. It will now wane, eventually passing around the back of the sun on Jan. 6, 2026, as it reaches superior solar conjunction. — Jamie Carter Since it reached first quarter phase, when half of its Earth-facing side appears lit as seen from our planet, the moon is now brightening the sky and making faint stars hard to see. However, it's a great time to see Maria (lunar "seas" of ancient lava in impact craters) on the moon. The most prominent are Mare Serenitatis (Sea of Serenity) and Mare Tranquillitatis (Sea of Tranquility), with three smaller maria beneath them: Mare Nectaris (Sea of Nectar), Mare Fecunditatis (Sea of Fertility) and Mare Crisium (Sea of Crises). — Jamie Carter The moon has been passing close to Antares — the brightest star in the Scorpius constellation — on every orbit this year, and tonight it will pass directly beneath it. Antares is one of four bright stars the moon regularly passes close to and occasionally occults, the others being Aldebaran in Taurus, Regulus in Leo and Spica in Virgo. That's because they lie near the ecliptic, which closely matches the moon's path through the sky. The close conjunctions and occultations occur in a predictable, repeating series over several years as part of the 18.6-year-long lunar cycle. — Jamie Carter If you've been thinking about Apollo 11 this month, 11 nights on from the 56th anniversary of its mission, it's finally a good night to look for where it landed on the moon. Anytime after sunset tonight, look at the now 39%-lit waxing crescent moon, more specifically at the terminator. Right in the middle of the moon, to the right of the terminator, is a dark patch — that's an ancient lava field called Mare Tranquillitatis — the Sea of Tranquility — where Neil Armstrong and Buzz Aldrin landed at 9:41 p.m. EDT on July 20, 1969. — Jamie Carter Related: Discover where the Eagle might have landed: How to find Apollo 11's backup sites on the moon The waxing crescent moon is such a beautiful sight for skywatchers during the week after a new moon. However, while watching its face gradually be revealed by sunlight is a treat, the moon also conducts a guided tour of some of the night sky's brightest stars. Drop in on the tour tonight, when it will hang just a degree or so from Spica, the brightest star in the constellation Virgo. Spica, a blue-white binary star, is 250 light-years from the solar system. Expect up to 20 "shooting stars" per hour at the peak of the Delta Aquariids tonight. The result of debris left in the inner solar system by comet Marsden and comet Kracht, an early-setting waxing crescent, should mean decent viewing conditions. As a bonus, it's also the peak night for the Alpha Capricornids, which promise another 5-10 "shooting stars" per hour. The farther south you are, the more meteors you're likely to see. If you want to get your eyes on something few other skywatchers ever do, be outside looking west immediately after sunset. On offer is a 2%-illuminated waxing crescent moon, just a day past its new moon phase. It will be very close to the northwestern horizon, so you'll need a low view (and a cloudless horizon), as well as a pair of binoculars. — Jamie Carter If yesterday's sight of a super-slender crescent moon was a difficult catch, tonight's is slightly easier and likely more rewarding. Tonight, the moon will be 6%-illuminated and a little easier to see, but it's what's nearby that will make it really special. Look about two degrees to the right of the moon, and you'll see the bright star Regulus, shining at 1.3 magnitude. The brightest star in the constellation Leo, "The Lion," Regulus, is over 70 light-years from the solar system. — Jamie Carter Higher in the west after sunset than it was last night, an 11%-illuminated waxing crescent moon will shine, with Mars to its upper left. The mostly dark face of the moon will catch Earth's reflected glow, giving it a faint shine. According to NASA, an astronaut standing on the moon at this time would see a spectacular, fully lit Earth, with the lunar surface around subtly lit by Earthshine, just as dark nights on Earth are lit by the light of the full moon. The phenomenon is easiest to see about three mornings before and the evenings after the new moon. — Jamie Carter Very early this morning, we see the peak of a minor meteor shower, the Piscis Austrinids. Expect about five meteors per hour, according to In-The-Sky.org. Come back many hours later, about 45 minutes after sunset, and look west for the lovely sight of a 19% waxing crescent moon to the left of Mars. It's all that remains of the stunning "planet parades" of February and March. The two solar system bodies will be separated by about a degree — the width of your little finger held against the sky. — Jamie Carter With a new moon tonight, there's no moonlight or distractions, so use the darkness well and find one of the oldest known naked-eye stars. A yellow dwarf like our sun, Mu Cassiopeia A is a whopping 12.7 billion years old. It's actually one star in a visual binary star system (also called a double star) called Marfak in the constellation Cassiopeia. Look for it above the north-northeast horizon tonight by first identifying the W-shape of Cassiopeia. Use the four outside stars of Cassiopeia and connect them towards the horizon to make a larger V-shape with a brighter star below — that's Marfak. Fittingly, its name means "the elbow." — Jamie Carter Here's a challenging one — but it will be worth the effort. This morning, rising in the east-northeast but never getting far from the horizon in twilight, a slender 3%-illuminated waning crescent moon will shine close to Jupiter. This is the final morning it's possible to see it before it heads into the glare of the sun to become a new moon. The moon at this stage of its orbit is typically very hard to pick out with the naked eye. However, using Jupiter as a guardrail will help. Locate the giant planet, shining at -1.8 magnitude, and look just to its left. They'll be about five degrees apart. You'll need a clear horizon. — Jamie Carter The waning crescent moon will have moved another 12 degrees east on its journey around Earth this morning. By now, it's close to the sun's glare, so low in the east and just 7%-illuminated. This final Earthshine morning will be the best, with the slender nature of the lunar crescent and the delicate impact of Earth's reflected light making the moon a drop-dead gorgeous sight — but there's much more to see. The moon will hang between Venus, to its right, and Jupiter, beneath it. Snake your way upwards from Jupiter to the moon, across to Venus and beyond to bright star Aldebaran in Taurus before heading up to the beautiful Pleiades. Now, head back to the horizon directly below the Pleiades and Aldebaran, and you may see Orion's belt shooting up. Six of the night sky's most beautiful and brightest objects in one (albeit early!) stargazing session! — Jamie Carter Prominent in the southeast right after dark and drifting across the south overnight is the Summer Triangle, a classic asterism that provides a staging post to swing the Milky Way. However, one of the Summer Triangle's bright stars, Deneb at top-left, is the lynchpin of the constellation Cygnus, "The Swan." Deneb is the tail of the swan, with Albireo in the center of the Summer Triangle as its head. Native American cultures see the same shape as a salamander, a crane and a skeleton bird. — Jamie Carter Having familiarised yourself with the Cygnus constellation last night, take a look at it again and see something completely different. This time, you're looking for a cross-shape, and all you need to do is ignore some of the wing stars of Cygnus, then turn the entire shape upside down in your head. With Deneb at the top and Albireo at the bottom. It's oddly not as famous as the Southern Cross in the Southern Hemisphere, but the Northern Cross is much larger and easier to find. It's worth considering the rarity of both of the major stars; Deneb is one of the farthest stars that can be seen with the naked eye at 2,600 light-years distant from the solar system, while Albireo is a double star — one yellow-orange and one blue — though they're not visible to the naked eye. — Jamie Carter Here comes the sky-watching highlight of the month. Rise early this morning and look to the east-northeast about 45 minutes before sunrise for the spectacular conjunction of the moon and an open cluster of stars, and on an auspicious day for space exploration. A 24%-illuminated waning crescent moon will shine within the Pleiades, also known as M45 and the Seven Sisters. As you look at Earthshine lighting up the dark portion of the moon, including its Sea of Tranquility, think of the monumental achievement of NASA's Apollo 11 mission. On this day in 1969, at 3:17 p.m. EDT, Neil Armstrong and Buzz Aldrin became the first humans to land on and walk on the lunar surface. "Houston, Tranquility Base here," said Armstrong. "The Eagle has landed." — Jamie Carter If you can get up early this morning, on offer is the beautiful sight of a 15%-illuminated waning crescent moon close to Venus. The planet will shine brightly at -3.9 magnitude to the lower right of the moon. Look to the east about 45 minutes before sunrise. Aldebaran, the brightest star in Taurus, will be close by, forming a star-planet-moon equilateral triangle. It's another Earthshine morning, with Earth's reflected light clearly visible on the unlit portion of the moon. — Jamie Carter Rising around midnight tonight will be a last-quarter moon when the lunar surface appears half-lit from Earth. It's the starting gun for 10 nights of dark, moonless evening skies, which kicks off with the first appearance of Perseid meteors. The most famous and one of the most prolific meteor showers of the year, the Perseids, will this year likely disappoint on its peak night — August 11/12 — because of a recent full moon. So begin watching for shooting stars tonight and through the rest of July. Just don't expect the 100-per-hour rate possible on peak nights. It's one of the largest constellations in the night sky and visible for many months, but few stargazers know much about Ophiuchus, 'The Serpent Bearer." It's known as the 13th sign of the zodiac because, like the others, it's on the ecliptic, so the sun passes through it for 18 days from November 30. Between Scorpius and the Summer Triangle, the vast Ophiuchus constellation largely has faint stars, but its brightest star, Rasalhague, is easy to find — and can even be used to make the Summer Triangle into a Summer Diamond. Inside Ophiuchus — though not visible to the naked eye — is Barnard's Star, one of the closest stars to the sun at just six light-years distant. — Jamie Carter Look east around midnight tonight, and you’ll see a 70%-illuminated waning gibbous moon shining about two degrees above the planet Saturn. They’ll shine together all night. You won’t see it — it’s just beyond the capability of the human eye — but Neptune will be very close to Saturn. Saturn will come to its bright opposition on September 21, 2025, by which time its rings will have opened up slightly after being precisely side-on in March. From mid-northern latitudes, you're only likely to see the tail of Scorpius, "The Scorpion," below which you'll see the bright red supergiant star Antares, which is also known as "The Scorpion's Heart." Look above the southeastern horizon for the three stars that comprise its claws — Achrab, Dschubba and Fang. Shaula, a bright blue star that marks the Scorpion's tail, could go supernova at any time. At just 587 light-years distant, it's one of the closest supernova candidates. — Jamie Carter With the moon still bright, stick to bright stars when you're outside at night. A great target is one of the lesser-known stars of the Summer Triangle, that vast asterism visible in the southeast immediately after dark. Attention usually focuses on Deneb and Vega, marking the top of the triangle. Instead, focus on Altair at the bottom, which, as well as being the point of the Summer Triangle, is also the brightest star in the constellation Aquila, "The Eagle." Altair is a mere 17 light-years distant. Flanking Altair is orangey Tarazed at 395 light-years and Alshain at 45 light-years, which collectively mark the head of the eagle. As a bonus, Aquila sits across the Milky Way; look below it for the richest, brightest core of our home galaxy. — Jamie Carter For weeks, Venus has been moving ever closer to the V-shape of stars that represents the core of the famous constellation Taurus, “The Bull.” This morning in the east, best viewed at least 45 minutes before sunrise, Earth’s sister planet will make its closest approach (about three degrees above) to the bright orange-yellow star Aldebaran. Above the pair will be the sparkling Pleiades open cluster of stars. Although this morning is the best time to view it, it will remain a notable sight until approximately July 18. Tonight, see the start of two minor meteor showers that combine to bring a steady stream of shooting stars to summer skies. Both the Delta Aquarid and Alpha Capricornid meteor showers begin tonight, both officially peaking on July 30, but in reality, any night in late July and early August is when you’ll see their prodigy. Today sees the rising of the first Summer full moon in the Northern Hemisphere. July's full moon has a few names, with its most popular in North America associated with the growth of new antlers on male buck deer. It's also called the Hay Moon and Thunder Moon. The moon will reach its full phase, which technically only lasts for a moment, at 4:37 p.m. EDT (2037 GMT). However, as always, the time to observe it will be as it appears on the southeastern horizon during dusk. Find out the exact time of moonrise where you are and be in a position to see it appear as a spectacular orange orb. As the night progresses, it will move into the southwestern sky, remaining remarkably low. That's because it's happening so soon after the Summer Solstice. Since the moon mirrors the sun, when the sun is high in the sky, the moon is low. From today through July 21, Venus will be as high in the pre-dawn night sky as it gets during its current apparition as the "Morning Star." For this short time, it will be a genuine night-time object instead of the twilight sight it so often is. See it about 30 minutes before sunrise, and it will be around 25 degrees above the east-northeast horizon. It’s been lost in the sun's glare for the past few weeks and has effectively gone unseen since May, but this morning, the gas-giant planet will re-emerge into the pre-dawn morning sky. This morning, it will appear in the constellation Gemini and shine at magnitude -1.9, rising just before the sun (though if you want to see it, prepare for an “is that it?!” kinda view). Meanwhile, Venus will begin to shine above the east, just above Aldebaran in Taurus, getting closest on July 13. Jupiter won’t be an impressive object until mid-August. It will reach its bright opposition — when Earth briefly sits between it and the sun — on January 10, 2026. A waxing gibbous moon, now 92%-illuminated, will tonight shine in the southeastern sky about four degrees below Antares. A red supergiant star about 550 light-years from the solar system in the constellation Scorpius, "the Scorpion," Antares translates to "rival of Ares" (Ares means Mars) because it sits close to the ecliptic, so the red planet passes close to it every few years. When that happens, they can be easily confused because Antares is a distinctive reddish color. However, there will be no confusion tonight because Mars will be on the opposite side of the sky in the west, in the constellation Leo. — Jamie Carter Although it was technically highest above the horizon on June 26 as seen from North America, today is when the "Swift Planet" Mercury is at its greatest elongation east. All that means is that Earth has a good view of Mercury as it appears to swing farthest from the sun from our point of view, in the evening sky. It's a view that has more to do with Earth's position in the solar system than Mercury's. It will shine at 0.5 magnitude, with Regulus in Leo and, beyond, Mars, to its upper left. — Jamie Carter Look to the northeast about an hour before sunrise, and you'll see the lovely sight of Venus, blazing away at -4.1 magnitude, close to the most beautiful open cluster of stars in the night sky, the Pleiades. Also called M45 and the Seven Sisters, it's bright because the light from its seven bright stars (and about 1,000 others) is shining on interstellar dust and causing a reflection nebula. Uranus is between Venus and the Pleiades, though at 5.8 magnitude, the eighth planet from the sun is too faint to see with the naked eye (and, besides, it's just a tiny blue dot even in a large telescope). — Jamie Carter Just as it did one lunar orbit ago, the moon, now an 86%-illuminated waxing gibbous, will shine close to the constellation Scorpius. It will approach its brightest star, giant Antares, on July 7, but tonight, it sits in the Scorpion's claws, three stars that trace out the celestial shape's pincers. Try to find the crescent of stars that make up the rest of the constellation. It's not that easy from mid-northern latitudes, where Scorpius rises in the east, moves along the southern horizon and sinks in the southwest. One reason of many to plan a stargazing trip to a more southerly location, or the Southern Hemisphere (though always plan to do that between last quarter moon and first quarter moon for dark moonless skies!). — Jamie Carter Go find your solar eclipse glasses. Is there an eclipse? No — the next one is on September 21, 2025, in the South Pacific, Antarctica and New Zealand. However, there is a reason for looking at the sun today. Earth is at what astronomers call aphelion, the point in its orbit at which it is furthest from the sun. Although it's only 1 arcminute smaller than at its perihelion (closest point) in January, it's a good excuse to look at the smallest possible sun in the daytime sky. Besides, you'll probably see sunspots. If you do, note where you think they are on the solar disk and compare them with the real-time HMI Intensitygram images of the sun from NASA's Solar Dynamics Observatory, which are published every few minutes. — Jamie Carter Today at 2:31 p.m. EDT, the moon reaches its first quarter phase, when it will appear half-lit as seen from Earth and shine in the southwestern night sky. Look to its left and you'll see bright star Spica, the brightest star in the constellation Virgo. Come back tomorrow, and the moon will have waxed to 62%-illuminated and be much closer to Spica; this time, at it's lower-left. On either night, below the two, will be the little-known constellation Corus, "The Crow." Its five main stars — Gienah, Kraz, Algorab, Minkar and Alchiba — should be relatively easy to find. — Jamie Carter Stargazing is best done little and often, typically in the early evening, which allows the new stars and constellations you learn to slowly sink in through repetition as the night sky gradually changes throughout the year. However, it is possible to cheat. Stay up until about 2:00 a.m. local time, and you'll see constellations rising that you otherwise wouldn't see for many weeks or months during the early evening. Rise at 2:00 a.m. tonight — perhaps while out camping in the balmy summer temperatures — and look east, and you'll see what is, in effect, the evening night sky for September, with the Great Square of Pegasus, an easy-to-recognise asterism, rising in the east below the Summer Triangle. — Jamie Carter Here's one more chance to see the crescent moon this month. Regaling the western horizon after dark tonight will be a now 33%-illuminated waxing crescent moon in an equidistant alignment with Mars and Regulus. Having pulled away from the brightest star in the constellation Leo, the red planet will gradually sink into the sun's glare, hanging on thanks to the lengthening nights but eventually disappearing by October to re-emerge in the pre-dawn sky. — Jamie Carter Look again to the west-northwest soon after dark for the best night of the month to see the crescent moon. Now almost 9%-illuminated and arguably at its most spectacular, it will also be much easier to find than yesterday, simply because it will be higher up in a darker sky for longer. Look for the reflected light of Earth on its dark side — Earthshine — and to its lower right for tiny Mercury, which will become harder to see over the next few nights as it sinks into the sun's glare. Tonight also sees the peak of the annual Bootid meteor shower, a minor affair that will see just a couple of meteors flying about from the constellation Boötes, "The Herdsman," from comet 7P/Pons-Winnecke. — Jamie Carter About 45 minutes after sunset tonight, a beautiful alignment will be visible above the western horizon. The most obvious will be a 16%-illuminated waxing crescent moon, with visible "Earthshine" on its darkened limb. Look to its upper left, and you'll see the bright star Regulus and, beyond it, Mars, creating a lovely panorama of three equidistant celestial bodies. It's also a good lesson in scale and the importance of our line of sight because although they all appear aligned, it's just an optical illusion. While the moon is tonight 237,700 miles (382,800 kilometers) distant, Mars is 178 million miles (286 million km), and Regulus is 79 light-years away. If the moon were just an inch away, Mars would be 62 feet away and Regulus about 31,000 miles away. Space is BIG! — Jamie Carter Look above the west tonight immediately after dark at what is perhaps the highlight of the month for anyone interested in exploring the night sky with the naked eye. A beautiful 24%-illuminated crescent moon? Yes — but there's something else. Look just above the curve of the lunar crescent and you'll see Mars, shining at 1.5 magnitude, looking like a cherry on top. With a conjunction this close — just a fifth of a degree apart as seen from North America — it likely won't come as a surprise to learn that from the Pacific Ocean close to northern South America, the moon will briefly occult Mars, according to In The Sky. Such a thing was spectacularly imaged on January 13, 2025, by a new telescope at Kitt Peak National Observatory near Tucson, Arizona. — Jamie Carter You'll need a low west-northwest horizon for this one, but it's worth making an effort to have a fine view of a slender moon close to Mercury and a couple of famous stars, all strung out in a curved, sickle-shaped formation. About 45 minutes after sunset tonight, a 3.4%-illuminated waxing crescent moon — making its first appearance in the post-sunset sky of its new orbit — will be positioned between two points of light. On its left will be Mercury, at its highest in the night sky of its current apparition (about 16 degrees as seen from mid-northern latitudes). It will shine at a magnitude of near-zero. To the right of the moon will be Pollux, then Castor, the two brightest stars in the constellation Gemini, 37 and 51 light-years from the sun, respectively. The four celestial bodies form an equidistant crescent, with about 2.5 degrees between each one, that will quickly sink into the horizon. — Jamie Carter At 5:33 a.m. EDT, the moon will be roughly between Earth and the sun as it reaches its new phase. That leaves the skies moonlight-free and, consequently, as dark as they get. However, in June in the Northern Hemisphere, it all depends on your latitude (if you're above 48.5 degrees north, then astronomical darkness — when the sun is 18 degrees below the horizon — doesn't occur for a few weeks on either side of the solstice). If it does get properly dark where you are, it's a good night to use binoculars or a small telescope to find objects beginning with 'M' in the night sky, such as the Great Hercules Cluster in the constellation Hercules (M13), the Ring Nebula in Lyra (M57) and the Lagoon Nebula in Sagittarius (M8). The 'M' comes from Charles Messier, a French comet-hunter who categorized 110 Messier objects— fuzzy objects in the night sky that could be confused with comets. He was born on June 26, 1730, exactly 295 years ago tomorrow. — Jamie Carter If you can access dark skies, late June is a great time to begin looking for the Milky Way. Although its arc of stars is always somewhat visible, from the Northern Hemisphere, we spend most of winter and spring looking only at its outer spiral arms. Come late June, the Milky Way's core begins to appear — and with the moon down, this week is perfect for finding it. You will, however, need to stay up late, with the couple of hours after midnight a good time to see it. Look due south; the band of stars will appear to stream down to the horizon through the Summer Triangle asterism — specifically from Deneb to Altair. — Jamie Carter Today is the solstice, the day the sun will not set at the North Pole and will not rise at the South Pole. Caused by Earth's axis being tilted about 23.5 degrees relative to its orbital plane around the sun — thus altering the amount of sunlight different parts of the globe receive at different times of the year (seasons!) — it marks the beginning of astronomical summer north of the equator (which is titled towards the sun) and winter in the Southern Hemisphere (which is tilted away from it). At 10:40 p.m. EDT, the midday sun somewhere on Earth will appear above the Tropic of Cancer, a line of latitude at 23.5 degrees north of the equator. Solstice is when the days begin to get shorter and nights longer in the Northern Hemisphere. That's good news for stargazers, who can tonight celebrate the arrival of warm nights by looking for the famous Summer Triangle asterism. Look east-northeast for the stars Vega (top), Deneb (lower-left) and Altair (lower-right) — a sign not only of summer but of the location of the arc of the Milky Way. — Jamie Carter This one's likely a bit of a challenge — as always with Mercury — but if you fancy seeing the "Swift Planet," then look west-northwest 45 minutes after sunset. You're looking for a slightly reddish point of light with two stars just above — Pollux and Castor in the constellation Gemini, The Twins." Early risers should know that from today through August 5, Venus will rise before 3 a.m. local daylight time. Catch it this morning about an hour before sunrise for a view of it beneath a 22%-illuminated waning crescent moon. — Jamie Carter Although there's a good distance between all three, looking east an hour before sunrise will get you a beautiful panorama of a 13%-illuminated waning crescent moon between a bright Venus on the right and the Pleiades open star cluster to the lower left. As well as the lovely sight of Earthshine on the moon's darkened limb, the tableau offers a good lesson in the brightness of objects in the night sky. The moon, the brightest object in the night sky, will shine at -8 magnitude, with Venus about half as bright at -4.2 magnitude, but the scale is logarithmic, with every 1 magnitude difference meaning about 2.5 times difference in brightness — so the moon will be about 33 times brighter than Venus this morning. Both will shine in the faint constellation Aries. — Jamie Carter Here comes one of the stargazing — and astrophotography — highlights of the month. However, it's not particularly convenient. Rising about 3:30 a.m. local time on the east-northeast horizon will be a slender 6%-illuminated waning crescent moon. That alone will look fabulous, but cast your eyes just above to its right and there, not half a degree away, will be the beautiful open cluster of stars called the Pleiades (also called the Seven Sisters and M45). As a bonus, Venus will be blazing away at 4.1 magnitude just to the right of the pair. — Jamie Carter Look to the eastern horizon in the predawn hours on June 20 to spot the waning crescent moon hanging in the constellation Pisces, with Saturn and Neptune to its right and the bright morning star Venus close to the horizon. This is a perfect opportunity to observe the dark basaltic plains of Mare Imbrium (Latin for the Sea of Rains) and Oceanus Procellarum (the Ocean of Storms) scarring the lunar surface. It is thought that Mare Imbrium was created in the wake of a giant impact that created a magma ocean over a thousand kilometers wide, which swiftly cooled in the frigid space environment. — Anthony Wood They may be just past their closest conjunction, but Mars and the bright star Regulus, in the constellation Leo, remain extremely close above the west immediately after dark tonight. The perfect opportunity, then, to gaze at the two and see how the red planet interferes with a popular asterism of springtime. An informal shape of stars beloved of stargazers, rather than an official constellation, the Spring Triangle consists of two stars above Mars and Regulus, Arcturus in the constellation Boötes and Spica in Virgo. If you want to make the Spring Triangle less lopsided, use Denebola — at Leo's rear-end — rather than Regulus. It's a great night to find vast asterisms like this because the moon tonight reaches its last quarter phase, rising around midnight, thus keeping the early evening night skies as dark as possible. However, with the solstice approaching, true darkness in the Northern Hemisphere is now in short supply. — Jamie Carter Although the conjunction between Mars and Regulus was at its best last night, it's virtually identical tonight, so it's worth another look. Visible above the west after dark, the conjunction is worth pondering for the contrast of colors it brings. Look carefully, and you'll see that the light from Mars is reddish (though some see a golden hue), while Regulus is more of an ice-white-blue color. Mars is named after the Roman god of war and Regulus, meaning "king," is known as the "heart of the Lion" because it's the brightest star in the constellation Leo. They'll be less than a degree apart tonight, with Mars just above Regulus. — Jamie Carter If you've been following the passage of Mars towards Regulus, the brightest star in the constellation Leo, tonight that journey peaks. Seen above the west after dark for a few hours, the red planet and the blue star will appear to be just seven-tenths of a degree — less than the width of an outstretched little finger — apart. What's more, while Mars will shine at 1.4 magnitude, Regulus will do so at a near-identical 1.35 magnitude. — Jamie Carter Read more: How to see Mars visit a bright star and the moon this June If you're yet to get to know the small but beautiful constellation Corona Borealis, the "Northern Crown," here's a good opportunity. Its lovely crescent of seven stars — found between the Boötes and Hercules constellations — is an entrancing sight in itself, but this season there's an ulterior motive. It's home to a dim star called T Coronae Borealis (also called T CrB and the "Blaze Star"), a nova that explodes every 80 years or so — and it's due to go nova during 2025. For its constellation, look about halfway between Arcturus and the bright star Vega high above the southeast. — Jamie Carter Stargazers have a mixed reaction to low-Earth satellites in the night sky. The sight of one streaking overhead can elicit delight in many beginners, particularly since you'll almost certainly see several more after you see one. This week, when darkness is hard to come by in the Northern Hemisphere, is the easiest time to see satellites (particularly just after sunset) simply because the sun doesn't get all that low beneath the horizon, so it's able to shine on satellites high above well after sunset. Heavens-Above is the place to find timings for satellites, notably SpaceX Starlink satellites, which are launched frequently and can sometimes be seen in swarms soon after. Just bear in mind that astronomers and astrophotographers tend to detest the Starlink constellation, which now numbers about 7,000 and routinely ruins scientific data and images of the night sky. Tonight's a good time to look for satellites because the 85%-illuminated waning gibbous moon won't rise until about two hours after sunset.— Jamie Carter We're well into the Noctilucent Clouds season, also called NLCs, which tend to appear in northern skies in June and July. They're not predictable, but they can bring a welcome dose of awe to stargazers in northern latitudes starved of true darkness at this time of year. Appearing as ghostly, wispy webs high up in Earth's atmosphere, they comprise frozen dust. Their position about 47-53 miles (76-85 kilometers) is why they shine at night, able to reflect light from the sun, which for Earthlings below is already beneath the horizon. The Kármán line — the official beginning of space — is defined as 62 miles (100 km) above sea level, which is why NLCs are sometimes called "space clouds." Many mistakenly think the North Star is the brightest in the night sky. If you stood facing east last night to see the Strawberry Moon appear in a blaze of orange light, turn 90 degrees to the right after dark tonight and gaze generally north. Find the seven bright stars of the Big Dipper/The Plough, which look like a kitchen ladle or a deep spoon. It will be in the northwestern night sky with its bowl closer to the horizon. Find the two stars at the end of its bowl, Merak and Dubhe. Mentally extend the distance between the two stars four times, and you'll cross a fairly empty part of the night sky before coming across a bright-ish star. That's Polaris, the North Star. It never appears to move because Earth's northern axis is pointed virtually straight at it. The moon reaches its full phase at 3:44 a.m. EDT (0744 GMT) today. If you want the most impactful view of the full moon this month, watch the moonset early this morning, which will occur shortly before sunrise. Many hours later, the full moon will rise in an already darkened sky for those in North America. A full moon rising is at its best when it rises about 20 minutes after sunset, when the landscape is still visible and the sky is still partly lit. The celestial mechanics don't work out that well today, with sunset and moonrise separated by almost an hour. Still, any moonrise is worth watching. This one will see the Strawberry Moon about 99%-illuminated, slightly on the wane. Although tomorrow is the official date of the full moon, tonight is when to watch it emerge from beneath the southeastern horizon. That's not only because it will be 99.7%-illuminated and so very close to full, but because the celestial mechanics work out better for a good view. Named after the ripening of strawberries in the Northern Hemisphere (yes, moon names are extremely hemispheric!) — though also known as the Rose Moon, Honey Moon and Flower Moon — the time to see this full moon will be moonrise where you are. Today, sunset and moonrise almost coincide, meaning the near-full moon will rise in a fairly bright sky. It will do so in the southeast — almost as far south as the moon can rise — because of what astronomers called its once-every-19-years lunar standstill. — Jamie Carter The largest object in the night sky and one of the largest stars visible to the naked eye come head to head tonight after dark. Look to the southeast about 45 minutes after sunset and you'll see a now 98%-illuminated waxing gibbous moon, by now looking almost full, close to the red supergiant star, Antares. The brightest star in the summer constellation of Scorpius, "The Scorpion," Antares will be to the lower left of the bright moon. The moon will appear just outside Scorpius's claws and later sink into the southwestern horizon, positioned just below Antares, in the gathering light of dawn. — Jamie Carter Today sees the first of three opportunities to see a conjunction between the two planets in the night sky that bear the least resemblance to each other — Jupiter and Mercury. Size-wise, it's not a fair fight — you could fit about 24,000 rocky Mercurys into gas giant Jupiter — and when it comes to brightness in the night sky, the "Swift Planet" usually comes off second best, too. However, today in the north-northwest, 45 minutes after sunset, the two will shine at a comparable magnitude. You'll need to find yourself a good, clear view low to the horizon, and be quick about it because the window to see these two worlds together is tight. It would also be wise to have binoculars with you (but don't use them until the sun has set). Here's a second chance to see the conjunction between Jupiter and Mercury, which will shine alongside each other for a short time in the north-northwest 45 minutes after sunset. A low view of the horizon will be necessary to see the two planets just a couple of degrees apart. If you saw a similar sight yesterday, you'll see that Mercury has risen slightly since then. That trend will continue over the next few days, with Jupiter headed the other way. The giant planet will soon drift into the sun's glare, passing behind the sun on June 24, only to re-emerge soon after in the pre-dawn morning sky. If you want to see something super-bright streak across the night sky with your naked eye, forget "shooting stars" and visit NASA's Spot The Station website. There, you'll find specific timings for your location for a pass overhead of the International Space Station, which can be searingly bright at this time of year from the Northern Hemisphere. That's because just after sunset, while it's dark all around you, the sun doesn't get that far beneath the horizon, so low-Earth satellites glint in the sunlight. A bright pass of the ISS at this time of year can really impress. — Jamie Carter The 77%-illuminated waxing gibbous moon will tonight shine to the right of bright star Spica, the brightest in the constellation Virgo. Look to the south after dark. Spica will be occulted by the moon early on June 6 as seen from a swathe of mostly uninhabited land in Antarctica, and the Indian Ocean — but also from the tip of southern Tasmania in Australia — according to In The Sky. — Jamie Carter The moon is an endlessly fascinating sight, but for stargazers, it begins to seriously bleach the night sky when it reaches beyond the first quarter phase. So, instead of trying to find faint constellations tonight, which will be a struggle, look again at the terminator on the moon. Thanks to the shadows it throws, this dividing line between lunar day and night tonight reveals two distinct geological features on the moon. Look at the lunar north and you'll see a semicircle of dark grey. This is the Imbrium Basin (Mare Imbrium), the moon's largest impact basin visible to us, slowly being revealed (you'll see more of it tomorrow). Look at the southern end of the terminator and you'll find the moon's Southern Highlands. — Jamie Carter The Red Planet may be well past its best, having reached its once-every-26-months bright opposition in January, but it's worth watching how it moves this month. Tonight, you can see it shining to the right of the bright star Regulus, the brightest in the constellation Leo, "The Lion," which is high in the southwest after dark. Mars will get ever closer to Regulus over the next two weeks, passing closest to it on June 16 and 17. Mars will eventually reach the back of the lion-shaped constellation on June 29, just as a crescent moon slides by. — Jamie Carter Tonight at 10:41 p.m. EDT, the moon reaches its first quarter phase, when it will appear half-lit as seen from Earth. It's merely a line-of-sight phenomenon since half of the moon is always being lit by the sun — the only exception is during a total lunar eclipse, when it travels through Earth's shadow in space (the next one of those occurs on September 7-8, 2025). Tonight is a great time to look at Mare Serenitatis — the Sea of Serenity — a dark area close to the terminator (the division between day and night). — Jamie Carter Although there will be a lovely 20%-illuminated waxing crescent moon in the west immediately after sunset, tonight is a good time to turn your attention to low in the east and northeast sky, where the Summer Triangle is rising. This three-pronged shape comprises the bright stars Vega, Deneb and Altair, but each belongs to its own constellation — Lyra, Cygnus and Aquila, respectively. The later you look, the higher these three constellations will appear in a darker sky — particularly after the moon has set about two hours after sunset. — Jamie Carter No, it's not convenient, but if you're of a mind to check in on Venus as it becomes more distant from Earth on its shorter journey around the sun, this is the morning to do that. Earth's sister planet reaches its greatest elongation west before sunrise this morning, when it will be 46 degrees in angular distance from the sun. Look east anytime before sunrise. Look up 45 minutes after sunset, and you'll see a lovely conjunction with a 29%-illuminated waxing crescent moon close to Mars, with Regulus in Leo beyond. — Jamie Carter As it approaches its half-lit first quarter phase, the moon — tonight 39%-illuminated — will be between the red planet Mars and a famous blue star, Regulus, in the constellation Leo. From North America, the moon will be closest to Regulus — less than two degrees — high in the southwestern sky. They'll be best seen an hour or two after sunset. — Jamie Carter Tonight's moon will look something like a smiley face. Now 12%-illuminated, the waxing crescent moon will put on a slightly lopsided smile, with two bright stars directly above as the eyes — Castor and Pollux in the constellation Gemini. The smiley face will be on show in the west about 45 minutes after sunset and set relatively soon after, so be quick. — Jamie Carter Tonight, the moon will be a slightly larger, brighter crescent. It will be higher in the sky, having moved slightly farther along its orbital path around Earth. Now 5%-illuminated, it will shine directly above Jupiter as seen from North America, above the west-northwest horizon. You'll easily see the dark limb of the moon illuminated by reflected light from Earth's oceans, clouds and ice caps, which is named variously as "Earthshine," "planet-shine" and "Da Vinci glow." — Jamie Carter If you're quick tonight and get outside 45 minutes after sunset, you may spot a razor-thin crescent moon in the northwest. Just over 1%-illuminated, you'll likely have to use binoculars, though there is a handy marker nearby — bright planet Jupiter. Find the giant planet close to the horizon and look to its lower right. A good, clear view low to the north-western horizon will be crucial. Since it's so tiny, astronomers often call this first sighting of the crescent the 'old moon in the new moon's arms.' — Jamie Carter If you want to catch a very slim-waning crescent moon — just 11%-illuminated — this is the morning to see it. Best seen about 45 minutes before sunrise where you are, the moon will be to the left of Venus, and very close to the horizon, above due east. — Jamie Carter Another early rise? Yes — but the prize this morning is a great view of the bright center of our galaxy. Best seen about an hour before sunrise at this time of year from the Northern Hemisphere, it will be streaming down the sky, and brightest in the south. As we get closer to summer, it will become visible after midnight, and eventually after sunset in early fall. Although it's a passion of many stargazers, astronomers, and astrophotographers north of the equator to see the Milky Way each summer, the best views are always from the Southern Hemisphere. That's because the galactic central point — where the stars are densest, and the light is brightest — is located in the direction of the Southern Hemisphere. From the Northern Hemisphere, we see the ends of the spiral arms. — Jamie Carter A new moon isn't something to see per se — it's roughly between the Earth and the sun, so invisible to us — but those in coastal areas are bound to feel the effect on tides of what is technically a "supermoon." Turning new at 10:02 EDT today, it's the third-closest new moon to Earth of 2025 at 223,720 miles (360,044 kilometers). With the moon out of the night sky, it's ideal for stargazing if the skies are clear — or take a star trail image, as shown above. Here's how to photograph a star trail. — Jamie Carter Here's another reason to get up about 45 minutes before sunrise. This morning, a 20%-illuminated waning crescent moon will be about four degrees from Venus, with Saturn above-right. Again, you'll need a view low to the eastern horizon and a clear sky. Look out for "Earthshine" on the moon's dark side. In late 2023 through mid-2024, Andreas Mogensen — the first Danish astronaut — studied Earthshine, measuring how much light reflected from the moon comes from the sun and how much is reflected from Earth. — Jamie Carter Waking up 45 minutes before sunrise is never easy, but that's the cost if you want to see some beautiful celestial panoramas this morning and through the weekend. You'll need a view low to the eastern horizon — a third-floor (or higher) window works well — as well as a clear sky. This morning, a 30%-illuminated waning crescent moon will be less than three degrees from Saturn, with Venus to the lower left, closer to the horizon. — Jamie Carter Last night's last quarter moon signals the beginning of a 10-night period when there is no bright moonlight in the pre-midnight hours. That makes them ideal for stargazing and astronomy. It's time to go learn some constellations! Start with something you know — like the Big Dipper — then come back here tomorrow to learn something new. As a reminder, the Big Dipper is an asterism — a shape of seven stars — that forms part of a bigger constellation called Ursa Major, the 'Great Bear.' — Jamie Carter You'll see thousands of images of the full moon and the half-lit first-quarter moon, but what about the "other" side? Images of the last quarter moon are rarer because it rises at midnight and sets at noon, as opposed to the first quarter moon, which rises at midday — and is already 'up' during twilight — and sets at midnight. Look for features on the westward face of the moon along the terminator (the line between light and shadow) including the Mare Imbrium (Sea of Rains) at the top, the large Ptolemaic crater in the center and the Montes Apenninus mountain range, the latter looking like a line of 'bubbles' at the bottom. — Jamie Carter With the waning gibbous moon rising just before midnight, you'll have most of the evening to find the summer constellation Scorpius, which the moon visited last week. Wait for Antares to appear in the southeast about two hours after sunset, then look above the red supergiant star for three bluish stars that trace the claws of the scorpion — Jaabbah (top), Acrab and Dschubba. These three stars are also known as the "Crown of the Scorpion." — Jamie Carter It's faint and requires dark skies and patience to find, but Ursa Minor, "The Little Bear" — also known as the Little Dipper — contains one of the most famous stars in the Northern Hemisphere's night sky. Ursa Minor is a circumpolar constellation, appearing to go round and round all night. There's a reason for that. At the tip of its handle is Polaris, the North Star, which Earth's northern axis points at. At the end of its bowl are Kochab and Pherkad, two stars known as the "Guardians of the Pole." The precession of Earth means that Kochab used to be close to the North Celestial Pole around 1800-1200 BCE, and will be again around 24,000 CE. — Jamie Carter Here comes perhaps the ultimate celestial signpost for stargazers each summer in the Northern Hemisphere. Look to the east a couple of hours after sunset, and you'll see, rising on its side, the glorious sight of the Summer Triangle stars. Why glorious? The Milky Way flows through this asterism (informal shape of stars) tonight as a horizontal band streaming from Deneb on the left to Altair on the right. Above is Vega. This asterism is also a study of how the brightness of stars isn't always indicative of how close they are. For example, Altair and Vega are 17 and 27 light-years distant, respectively, while Deneb is a mighty 1,500 light-years away. It's the farthest bright star. A blue-white supergiant about 200 times larger than the sun, Deneb is one of the biggest stars we know of. — Jamie Carter Go outside a couple of hours after dark, armed with some patience, and you'll have a chance to see one of the most famous constellations. However, the Hercules constellation is fainter than you might think. The core of the spider-like figure is a lopsided square of four stars known as the keystone. You'll find it by first locating bright star Vega above the east (the highest star in the Summer Triangle) and Arcturus high in the south, which you can do by going "arc to Arcturus" using the curve of stars in the handle of the Big Dipper. The keystone stars are about a third of the way along that line, closest to Vega. Within the square is M13, the "Great Globular Cluster" in Hercules — over 100,000 ancient stars orbiting in the Milky Way's halo. — Jamie Carter With the waning gibbous moon now 89%-illuminated and rising about three hours after sunset, it's a good time to find a seasonal shape of stars now prominent in the southwest right after dark. The three constituent stars are Arcturus, Spica and Regulus in the constellations Boötes, Virgo and Leo, respectively. Arcturus will be on the left, with Spica below, and Regulus off to the right. Just beyond Regulus will be Mars. — Jamie Carter Tonight, a 94% waning gibbous moon will rise in the east a couple of hours after sunset, which is a great time to get outside and watch a moonrise. Once it's up, you'll see that the top-right of the moon, as we look at it from the Northern Hemisphere, is in darkness, with the terminator — which separates day and night on the moon — slicing through some interesting terrain. The shadows will make it relatively easy to see Mare Crisium, the "sea of crises," as well as some obvious craters along the top of the moon. Binoculars will give you a tremendous view. Related: Moon viewing guide: What to look for on the lunar surface Tonight, the moon meets the "rival of Mars." The now 94%-illuminated waning gibbous moon will rise a couple of hours after sunset, again appearing in the south just a third of a degree (less than the width of your little finger held at arm's length) from red supergiant star Antares in the constellation Scorpius, "the Scorpion." Look for Antares to the left of the moon. Its name translates to "rival of Ares" (Ares means Mars), not only because of its reddish color but also because it sits close to the ecliptic, so the red planet passes close to it every few years. About 550 light-years from the solar system, Antares has another nickname — the "Scorpion's Heart." — Jamie Carter At 11:56 a.m. EDT today, 100% of the moon will be illuminated by the sun — a full moon. The best time to watch May's "Flower Moon" will be moonrise where you are (which is specific to your location), where you can watch it come up from beneath the southeastern horizon. Thanks to Raleigh scattering, there's a short period of about 15 minutes where a full moon is a muted orange, then pale yellow. It's a great time to look at the moon with your naked eyes or a pair of binoculars. Once it's risen high into the sky, it will quickly become too bright to look at comfortably. — Jamie Carter A full moon is coming, but before it arrives, our natural satellite will pass closely to another key bright star of the spring night sky in the Northern Hemisphere. About 94%-illuminated, the waxing gibbous moon will sit about half a degree (less than the width of your little finger held at arm's length) from Spica, which may appear as one point of light but is actually the combined light of two blue giant stars in a binary star system. It's about 250 light-years from the solar system. The moon will be easy to see in the southeast even before sunset, with Spica appearing on its lower left during twilight. — Jamie Carter It may be 400,000 times less bright than the sun, but it's often very easy to see the moon during the day. At first quarter, it rises at noon and sets at midnight, while at full moon a week later it rises at sunset and sets at sunrise. In between, it's big, bright, and high in the southeast all afternoon. Today, it will become very obvious in the east about an hour before sunset in the west, and dominate the dusk. — Jamie Carter Expert moon watchers will tell you not to look at the moon only when it's full or near-full, as it is tonight at 99.5% illuminated. That's true — studying features along the terminator, the dividing line between light and shadow, is the way to go — but looking at the entire Earth-facing side does give you a sense of lunar geography. The most prominent feature is its many maria — seas of ancient lava. Lava flows formed these darker areas on the lunar surface during its formation. It's also worth considering that the moon looks "upside down" when viewed from the Southern Hemisphere, where the moon — which roughly follows the sun's path through the sky — appears in the northern sky. — Jamie Carter If you're going to be a stargazer and navigate the night sky, you need to know about Arcturus. A red giant star 37 light-years from the solar system is easy to find — and not just because it's the fourth-brightest star in the night sky. Just follow the stars of the Big Dipper's handle to go in an "arc to Arcturus" in the east, towards — but not as far as — the 89%-illuminated waxing gibbous moon in the southeast. The constellation that Arcturus is part of, Boötes "The Herdsman," is to the left of the star. Given that the Big Dipper is part of the constellation Ursa Major, "The Great Bear," it's perhaps not surprising that Arcturus means "Guardian of the Bear." — Jamie Carter It’s one of the official 88 constellations, and it’s easy to see in the night sky, so why is the kite-shaped constellation Corvus “The Crow” so little known? In the southern sky immediately after dark and below the 82%-illuminated waxing gibbous moon, its five main constituent stars — Gienah, Kraz, Algorab, Minkar and Alchiba — should be relatively easy to find just to the right of bright star Spica. If not, come back in a week when the moon will be out of the sky. — Jamie Carter Today, it’s exactly two years since King Charles III was coronated. So why not find a star (kinda) named after him, Cor Caroli? Meaning “Charles’s Heart,” Cor Caroli is actually named after King Charles I or II — nobody is quite sure which one. Anytime after dark, look north for the Big Dipper. Find the star at the end of its handle, Alkaid, then go directly above about the same length as the handle. Part of the two-star constellation Canes Venatici, Cor Caroli is a binary star system about 110 light-years from the solar system. Tonight, it’s around a third of the way between Alkaid and the 74%-illuminated waxing gibbous moon in the east. — Jamie Carter Once the moon has reached about a third-lit, it begins to become bright and less interesting to see with the naked eye. However, it's worth looking for tonight because it will form a nice triangle with a planet and a star. Now 34%-illuminated and visible from sunset until midnight, it will hang below Mars and to the upper-right of Procyon, the eighth-brightest star in the night sky and the brightest (and only notable) star in the constellation Canis Minor. — Jamie Carter At 45%-illuminated, the moon is tonight perilously close to reaching its First Quarter phase, where its brightness begins to bleach the light sky. However, tonight, it should be a target for skywatchers as it is very close to Mars. Its exact position will depend on where you are and when you look, but from many locations, the moon will be perched just above Mars — a stunning sight! If you have a pair of binoculars, it will get even better, because Mars will be beside the stunning Beehive Cluster open cluster of stars. — Jamie Carter Tonight, the moon reaches its first quarter phase, which makes all but the brightest stars harder to see. So why not focus on those brightest stars? Look to the west about 45 minutes after sunset, and you'll see bright Jupiter due west. High to its right side will be bright Capella in Auriga, the "Goat Star," while to its lower left will be Betelgeuse in Orion and, closer to the horizon, Sirius in Canis Major. The four will together form a cosmic curve above the western horizon. — Jamie Carter Now 24%-illuminated, the waxing crescent moon will tonight hang roughly halfway between Mars, to its upper left and Jupiter, to its lower right. Look to the western sky from about 45 minutes after sunset. — Jamie Carter Tonight is your second chance in a row to see a waxing crescent moon shining close to bright Jupiter. This time, the moon will be 14%-illuminated and appear just above Jupiter. They'll be roughly equidistant between two bright stars, Betelgeuse in Orion to the lower left and bright Capella in Auriga to the upper right. — Jamie Carter Here's the first of two successive opportunities to see the beautiful crescent moon visit the biggest planet in the solar system. Look to the western sky about 45 minutes after sunset, and you'll see a 7%-illuminated waxing crescent moon approaching Jupiter, shining at mag. 2. The two will form a triangle with red supergiant star Aldebaran below, the brightest star in the constellation Taurus, which Jupiter is currently residing within. — Jamie Carter Look to your east this morning about 45 minutes before sunrise, and you'll see a beautiful planetary view. The most obvious world will be Venus, which will shine at mag. -4.4, though barely two degrees below it will be Saturn shining at mag. 1.2. That makes Venus 174 times brighter than Saturn tonight. If you're lucky, you may also see Mercury much closer to the horizon, due east. For a bonus sight, be outside shortly after sunset, and you will stand a slim chance of seeing a very slender crescent moon just above the western horizon. Since it will be 2%-illuminated, this is going to be a challenging observation, but it is possible to see such a slim moon. Although you may be able to see it with the naked eye, a pair of binoculars will help hugely, particularly because the beautiful Pleiades open cluster of stars will be positioned just above the crescent moon. — Jamie Carter If you've only got the time, energy or inclination to get up before sunrise just once this month to do astronomy, make it this morning. About 45 minutes before sunrise in the east an 8% illuminated waning crescent moon will form a tight equilateral triangle with Venus and Saturn, with no more than a couple of degrees between all three solar system bodies. It's undoubtedly the observing and astrophotography highlight of the week and, arguably, the month. Look carefully; you may see Mercury below the crescent moon, shining at mag. 0.4. — Jamie Carter Here's an interesting bright star to bright planet hop that won't be possible in the evening sky for much longer. Be outside shortly after sunset, looking west, and you should easily be able to pick out the planet Jupiter, shining at mag. -1.9 in the constellation Taurus. To its lower left will be Betelgeuse, a mag. -0.5 reddish star directly above the unmistakable three stars of Orion's Belt. Go the same distance again toward the southwest, and you'll come to Sirius, the brightest star in the night sky at mag. -1.
